title: CAN SCORE-BASED GENERATIVE MODELING EFFECTIVELY HANDLE MEDICAL IMAGE CLASSIFICATION?
author: Sushmita Sarker (University of Nevada, Reno), Prithul Sarker (University of Nevada, Reno), George Bebis (University of Nevada, Reno), Alireza Tavakkoli (University of Nevada, Reno)
relevance_why: The generative approach and the application of score-based models could inspire new methods for audio restoration and enhancement tasks, particularly in handling limited or imbalanced data.
background: The study investigates the efficacy of score-based generative models for classifying medical images, specifically mammograms, where data is limited and imbalanced.
contribution: This paper introduces a score-based generative model for medical image classification to address challenges of limited data, achieving improved accuracy compared to traditional discriminative models.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods mainly relied on discriminative models that can falter when class distributions overlap significantly, leading to overfitting.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work employs score-based generative models to capture underlying class distributions, enhancing robustness even with limited or imbalanced datasets.

key_innovation: Utilizes score-based generative modeling to effectively handle challenging classification tasks in medical imaging, allowing for improved accuracy without requiring extensive data.
real_world_impact: The findings could significantly enhance diagnostic accuracy in healthcare settings by leveraging limited data more effectively through generative modeling techniques.

new_terms.score-based generative models: **Score-based generative models** are a class of generative models that represent the data distribution using the gradients of the probability density function, allowing for effective sampling and representation in complex data spaces.

open_sourcing: The code is publicly available at https://github.com/sushmitasarker/sgc_for_medical_image_classification
